channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Putin Mobilizes More Troops; Prisoner Exchange Announced
item.description: In a rare address to Russia, the Russian president made a veiled threat of using nuclear weapons. Two U.S. military veterans were released in a prisoner exchange.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers securing an area on Tuesday in Kupiansk, a town in eastern Ukraine that was retaken from Russian forces.

item.title: U.N. Live Updates: Biden Says Russia’s Aim Is ‘Extinguishing Ukraine’s Right to Exist’
item.description: Ukraine was a central focus of the second day of speeches at the U.N. General Assembly, as leaders from around the globe took the stage.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden urged continued international solidarity with Ukraine at the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday.

item.title: Victims Recall Life in the Philippines Under Marcos’s Martial Law
item.description: Ferdinand E. Marcos placed the country under military rule 50 years ago this week. With his son now in power, those who lived through those dark days fear their stories will be lost.
item.dc:creator: Jes Aznar and Jason Gutierrez
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Protests in Iran Intensify Over Woman Who Died in Custody
item.description: Unrest has spread to dozens of cities, with at least seven people killed, according to witnesses, rights groups and video posted on social media.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Protesters in Tehran on Thursday. Unrest erupted last weekend after Mahsa Amini died in police custody following an arrest under the law on head scarves.

item.title: Russia Signals Annexation of Parts of Ukraine, Raising Stakes in Fighting
item.description: Kremlin-backed officials in four partially occupied regions announced referendums on joining Russia, as Moscow tightens its grip and hints at escalation.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A billboard in Luhansk, Ukraine, on Tuesday advertising “The Future of the Luhansk People’s Republic.” Luhansk is the capital of one of the two provinces of eastern Ukraine with Russian-backed insurgencies that President Vladimir V. Putin declared independent in February.

item.title: For Churches, Abortion Politics Is a Double-Edged Sword
item.description: Ireland and Poland went in entirely opposite directions on abortion. Why?
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Supporters celebrate at Dublin Castle after a constitutional amendment legalizing abortion passed in 2018.

item.title: How ‘Lord of the Rings’ Inspires Italy’s Giorgia Meloni
item.description: Giorgia Meloni, the nationalist politician who is the front-runner to become prime minister, sees “The Lord of the Rings” as not just a series of novels, but also a sacred text.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: As a youth activist, Giorgia Meloni revered “The Lord of the Rings” and other works by the British writer J.R.R. Tolkien.

item.title: French Left Lawmaker Admits Slapping Wife, and Party Leader Defends Him
item.description: Jean-Luc Mélenchon, the leader of the leftist France Unbowed party, expressed “trust” and “affection” for Adrien Quatennens, setting off a firestorm.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Adrien Quatennens, shown last month speaking in the National Assembly in Paris, said he would step down from his role as a top coordinator for the France Unbowed party.

item.title: Russia’s Invasion Shadows U.N. Assembly Amid ‘Colossal Global Dysfunction’
item.description: Presidents Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey and Emmanuel Macron of France used the gathering as a stage to cast themselves as would-be peacemakers in the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: António Guterres, the United Nations secretary general, said in his opening remarks that the world is in peril: “We cannot go on like this.”

item.title: On a Grim Anniversary, 230 Pilot Whales Are Stranded in Tasmania
item.description: “At least 95 percent will die, because the ocean’s just so fierce,” said a boat skipper on the scene, where 470 whales were also beached in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Department of Natural Resources and Environment Tasmania, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Pilot whales stranded on the western coast of Tasmania on Wednesday.

item.title: Prime Minister Liz Truss Pivots From Queen’s Funeral to U.K.’s Crises
item.description: Liz Truss’s government will roll out major initiatives to confront an array of economic and social problems: soaring energy costs, surging inflation and pressure on public services.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain is in New York this week, where she is holding diplomatic meetings on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly.

item.title: Egypt Feels Pain of Global Disruptions Wrought by War and Pandemic
item.description: The country’s economy has been very hard hit by cascading crises which have disrupted worldwide trade.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Dates and other dried fruit on sale at a market in central Cairo. In March, the Egyptian central bank devalued the currency by about 14 percent and prices shot up.

item.title: In One Corner of Kosovo, Cheers Still Ring Out for Putin
item.description: Many ethnic Serbs, nursing grievances against NATO for a 1999 bombing campaign that broke Serbia’s grip on the territory, see President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia as a potential savior.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Armend Nimani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Statues in Mitrovica honor Prince Lazar, left, a Christian Serb ruler at the Battle of Kosovo in 1389 and Grigory Scherbina, right, a Russian envoy to the region.

item.title: Ten Prisoners, Including Americans, Have Been Released in a Russia-Ukraine Exchange
item.description: Alex Drueke, a former U.S. Army staff sergeant who served two tours in Iraq, and Andy Tai Ngoc Huynh, a former U.S. Marine, were released.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Jeronimo Nisa/The Decatur Daily, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Andy Tai Ngoc Huynh in Hartselle, Ala., in April.

item.title: President Raisi Addresses U.N. General Assembly Amid Protests in Iran
item.description: “We are the defenders of a fight against injustice,” President Ebrahim Raisi told the U.N. General Assembly as his government faces widespread protests over the rights of women.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran made his first appearance at the United Nations headquarters in New York on Wednesday.

item.title: One-Way Flights From Russia Are Selling Out or Skyrocketing in Price
item.description: Some Russians rushed to buy airfare after President Vladimir V. Putin ordered up reservists to bolster the country’s military in Ukraine. Tickets to some visa-free destinations are sold out for several days.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Tickets to some of the most popular visa-free destinations out of Moscow are either sold out or are skyrocketing in price.

item.title: John Train, Paris Review Co-Founder and Cold War Operative, Dies at 94
item.description: His career, ranging from literature to finance to war, and from France to Afghanistan, seemed to cover every interest and issue of his exalted social class.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Story of Russia’ by Orlando Figes
item.description: In a new book, the historian Orlando Figes argues that the war on Ukraine is only the latest instance of a nation twisting the past to justify its future.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Feifer
item.media:description: The 2016 unveiling of a Moscow monument to Grand Prince Vladimir, who is credited with bringing Orthodox Christianity to what became Russia.

item.title: E.U. countries ask the U.N to appoint a monitor to assess human rights violations in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shop at army games in the Moscow region in August.

item.title: The Theater at War
item.description: In shows like “The Burnt City,” the chaos of war meets the curated artifice of performance, our critic writes. But “Oresteia” took a different view, and the audience was better for it.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips

item.title: A Cornered Vladimir V. Putin is More Dangerous Than Ever
item.description: In a major speech, he recast the war in Ukraine and made clear it could spread.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: By calling up roughly 300,000 reservists to fight, and abandoning the objective of demilitarizing and “de-Nazifying” Ukraine, President Vladimir Putin of Russia acknowledged the reality and growing resistance of a unified Ukraine.

item.title: German Far-Right Politicians Cancel Trip to Russian-Occupied Part of Donbas
item.description: The planned visit by state politicians of the Alternative for Germany party was controversial, with critics saying it would chip away at national unity over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Volunteers helping to evacuate civilians from Bakhmut, a Ukrainian-controlled city in Donbas that has endured relentless Russian shelling.

item.title: Iran’s President Speaks at U.N. as Protests Rock His Nation
item.description: The Iranian president, who came to power last year, will address the assembly amid large demonstrations at home and international pressure to revive the Iran nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran at a news conference in Tehran last month.

item.title: China offers a muted response to Putin’s announcement as it tries to maintain ties to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Sergei Bobylyov/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse —Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russian, left, and Xi Jinping, China’s leader, meeting in Uzbekistan last week.

item.title: A Shrinking Margin
item.description: Democrats lost ground with Hispanic voters in 2020. It doesn’t seem to have been a blip.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eric Trump in 2020 at a Latinos for Trump event in Phoenix.

item.title: Global leaders condemn planned referendums in Russian-occupied parts of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: A vehicle on fire after shelling in the Russian-occupied area of Donetsk in Ukraine on Saturday.

item.title: Russia’s gas cutoff is ravaging manufacturers in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Glass stems on a conveyor belt at Arc International in France. The company needs natural gas to make its glassware, but Europe’s energy crisis has caused gas prices to surge.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Occupation officials in four Ukrainian regions announced on Tuesday plans to hold referendums to join Russia.

item.title: Royal Shakespeare Company Names Two Directors for Top Job
item.description: In an unusual move for a major British theater, Daniel Evans and Tamara Harvey will jointly helm the major British theater troupe.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Daniel Evans and Tamara Harvey will start work as the Royal Shakespeare Company’s new artistic directors in June.

item.title: Al Gore Calls the World Bank Chief a ‘Climate Denier’
item.description: The former vice president also said President Biden should seek to have the Trump-nominated bank leader, David Malpass, removed from his role.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:description: David Malpass was nominated to lead the World Bank by former President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia Moves Toward Annexation
item.description: Plus leaders address a world in peril at the U.N. General Assembly and protests sweep Iran.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: An apartment building was heavily damaged by Russian bombs overnight in Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: The Ukrainian Frontline Town of Siversk Is Cut Off From the World
item.description: After the Ukrainian military’s sweeping victory in the northeast last week, the fate of Siversk, in the Donbas region, appears once more undecided.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Dimitry Yatsenko
item.media:description: Ukrainian civilians evacuating from the frontline city of Siversk, in the Donbas region, on Tuesday.

item.title: Putin’s Address to Russia Delayed After Hours of Waiting
item.description: The Kremlin did not explain why it was delayed — or even that it had been planned at all. But the caginess telegraphed the rapid speed — and apparent improvisation — with which Moscow is plotting out its next moves.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in Kupiansk, where the Ukrainian military pushed Russian forces back across the Oskil River in recent days.

item.title: U.S. Shores Up Ukraine Aid as Energy Crisis in Europe Looms
item.description: The Biden administration is trying to keep its allies on board as the Russian invasion has sent energy prices soaring.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian solder near the city of Izium. A large share of the weapons that Ukraine’s military has received have come from the United States.

item.title: Apps Like Flashfood and Too Good to Go Let You Buy Food That Was Going to be Thrown Away
item.description: Several companies say they are tackling food waste by connecting people with unsold food from restaurants and grocery stores.
item.dc:creator: Clare Toeniskoetter
item.media:credit: Lawrence Agyei for The New York Times

item.title: Russian Oil Price Cap Will Be a Focus of the U.S. and Its Allies
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: A tanker at a crude oil terminal near Nakhodka, Russia, in August. American officials will be gauging reactions from various countries about a price cap on Russian oil exports at the General Assembly this week.

item.title: Ukraine Advances Deeper Into Areas Held By Russia
item.description: The Ukrainian military has not declared victory yet in Bilohorivka, given that control over towns has proved tenuous in the past. Reclaiming it would signal that Russia no longer has full control of the Luhansk region.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Civilians watched from a street corner in Bakhmut as Ukrainian military vehicles headed on Monday in the direction of the front line in the Donbas region.

item.title: 1922: Ex-Kaiser to Marry Princess Hermine
item.description: Wilhelm II, who abdicated as emperor of Germany in the midst of defeat in World War I, had become a widower in 1921.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Turkey’s President Says Russia Should Return Captured Ukrainian Territories
item.description: Erdogan has positioned himself as a mediator between Ukraine and Russia and hosted preliminary peace talks in Istanbul in March.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Alexandr Demyanchuk/Sputnik, via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, left, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met on the sidelines of a summit in Uzbekistan on Friday.

item.title: Here’s what to expect as world leaders address the United Nations.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Traffic was restricted near United Nations Headquarters on Monday as the General Assembly prepared to meet.

item.title: Sarah Koenig, the Host of ‘Serial,’ Talks About Adnan Syed’s Release
item.description: We talk with Sarah Koenig, host of the “Serial” podcast.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adnan Syed, whose case was chronicled on the podcast “Serial,” exited the courthouse to a crowd of supporters on Monday.

item.title: How a 79-year-old Film Director Learned to “Fly” on a Trapeze
item.description: Tom Moore made a name for himself as a film, TV and theater director. But his dream has always been to “fly” on the trapeze, high in the air. And that’s what he is doing at age 79.
item.dc:creator: Abby Ellin

item.title: Protests Erupt in Iran After Woman’s Death in Custody
item.description: The 22-year-old’s death sparked outrage across social, religious and political factions. Four people were reported to have been killed by the security forces.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: A protest in downtown Tehran on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The funeral of Queen Elizabeth II.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral procession of Queen Elizabeth II yesterday.

item.title: Russia is struggling to attract new recruits for its army, a U.S. official says.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: An abandoned Russian tank with the “Z” symbol in Izium last week, during a media tour arranged by the Ukrainian government after the city was reclaimed.

item.title: Pentagon Orders Review of Its Overseas Social Media Campaigns
item.description: The move comes after Twitter and Facebook shut down misleading accounts that they determined were sending messages to promote U.S. foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pentagon has ordered a review of secretive operations to influence populations overseas after White House officials expressed concerns.

item.title: Strike Near Another Ukrainian Nuclear Plant Escalates Fears of Disaster
item.description: A powerful Russian missile hit 300 yards from the plant far from the front lines, Ukraine said, a reminder that despite its recent retreat, Russia can still threaten nuclear sites.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: The South Ukraine Nuclear Power Plant in Yuzhnoukrainsk, Ukraine, about 70 miles north of the city of Mykolaiv, in 2015.
